Zr doped Rh-La2Ti2O7 with different amounts of Zr were prepared with a sol-gel process and used as catalysts for dry reforming of methane. The samples as prepared were characterized by a series of methods including powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS), and temperature-programmed reduction (TPR). The XPS and XAS spectra revealed the effect of doped Zr in the electronic environment of catalysts. The results showed that when the doping amount of Zr was at a low level, the activity and stability of the DRM catalyst were significantly improved. Tests of catalytic activity showed that the reforming performance of Rh-LTZO-x catalysts was affected by the Zr/Ti loading ratio. It was favored when Zr/Ti ratio was low and incomplete methane conversion was observed when Zr/Ti=1. Compared to Rh-LTO, the optimized catalyst Rh-LTZO-10 enhanced conversion of methane and carbon dioxide from 77% to 86%, 83% to 90%, respectively. The optimized catalyst Rh-LTZO-10 exhibited long stability life over 200 h of the reaction and there was only a small amount of carbon deposition. The low amount of Zr doping may accelerate the transfer rate or number of electrons during the reaction, enhance the interaction between the active component Rh and the support, so that Rh can stably exist in the structure and achieve long stability in DRM reaction. Keywords Dry reforming of methane (DRM) Heterogenous catalysis Long stability Rh catalyst Zr promoter Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As the simplest hydrocarbon with the chemical formula CH4, methane can be used as a fuel and as a raw material to produce hydrogen, carbon monoxide, acetylene, formaldehyde, and hydrocyanic acid. And it is also a major component of natural gas, biogas, and pit gas, and is widely distributed in nature. Furthermore, carbon dioxide is one of the major industrial exhaust gases and is widely known as a greenhouse gas and the increasing emissions of methane and carbon dioxide has led to the aggravation of greenhouse effect [1,2]. While dry reforming of methane (DRM) just transforms methane and carbon dioxide to syngas, which is suitable for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis to synthesize products like light olefins, higher alkanes and oxygenated chemicals [3,4], thus it has attracted numerous researchers. However, high operating temperatures (usually 600–800 °C) are required to obtain good yields, which results in the main problems of DRM reaction including catalyst sintering, side reactions, and serious carbon deposition. Therefore, how to improve the life of the catalyst has become the current research focus. To effectively increase the stability of the catalyst, that is, to suppress or reduce the occurrence of deactivation phenomena such as carbon deposition or sintering of the catalyst, researchers have developed a series of methods. The addition of metal promoters is one of the effective ways to improve the performance of catalysts. Song et al. have found that defect-free magnesium oxide supported Ni-Mo displayed industrially and economically viable path for DRM, which exhibited ultra-long stability without deactivation for 850 h [5,6]. Zhang et al. found that the addition of Fe to Ni-MgO to form Fe-Ni alloys increased its resistance to carbon deposition in the DRM reaction. Although the catalytic activity of Ni was reduced, the resistance to carbon deposition was improved. Besides, the addition of Fe enhanced the oxygen affinity and reduced the overall particle size [7]. In addition, researchers also find that when composite metal oxides are used as supports, the stability is greatly improved [8–12]. Perriot et al. used molecular dynamics models to study ion diffusion in A2B2O7 composite metal oxides, founding that the type of grain boundary, the composition of compounds (different A, B metals), and the degree of disorder of ions all have an impact on ion diffusion. This means that it is available to adjust the A2B2O7 structure as needed. Under external stimuli (such as temperature, radiation, doping, etc.), it may undergo cation exchange (A and B) to become disordered or cause vacancies migration, inducing surface reconstruction [13,14]. Zhang et al. used the physical vapor deposition (PVD) method to prepare the 0.15Ru/MgAl2O4 catalyst for 600 h of continuous reaction in an 850 °C micro-reactor, and its performance did not decrease but even increased by 1.5 times. It was attributed to the continuous growth of Ru particles as the reaction time progressed [15]. Spivey's group found that when using different metals such as Ni, Rh, Ru, Pt for modifying La2Zr2O7, it showed great performance differences in DRM reactions [16–19]. In our previous work [20], it was found that single atom Rh based Rh-La2Zr2O7 catalyst (Rh-LZO) performed excellent CH4 decomposition activity, while the reaction was terminated due to severely carbon deposit. In stark contrast, the nanoparticle Rh based Rh-La2Ti2O7 (Rh-LTO) is conducive to the dissociation of CO2 and the following migration of oxygen species, so that the intermediate carbon can be oxidized timely, but the ratio of H2/CO decreased with time on stream, which means the presence of side reaction such as reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS). If the advantages of both Rh-LZO and Rh-LTO can be combined, the major problems of carbon deposition and selectivity in the DRM reaction could be solved at the same time. In this article, we have optimized the formerly developed Rh-La2Ti2O7 catalyst through limited Zr doping to elevate the performances of DRM reaction. The results showed that when the doping amount of Zr was relatively low (x ≤ 10 in this work), the conversion of methane and carbon dioxide increased; but when the doping amount of Zr further increased to 50%, the activity was greatly reduced. With the appropriate amount of Zr doping (Rh-LTZO-x, where x = 5–10), active component Rh can be stable in the structure and performed ultra-long stability in DRM reaction. In response to this result, we analyzed the physical and chemical properties of the catalysts and discussed the reaction mechanism in detail. Research findings provide ideas for designing more stable DRM catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of samples The raw materials were commercially available without further purification. The preparation method of the catalyst is similar to our previous research [20]. The difference is that before adding citric acid for complexation, different amounts of Zr salt precursor are added to the mixed solution. Before characterization and evaluation, the prepared catalyst was reduced by 10% H2/He at 800 °C for 1 h. 2.2 Characterizations The actual content of metals in the samples were determined using an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES; Jobin Yvon, Ultima-2). To analyze phase structures and crystallinities, the X-ray diffractometer was used (XRD; Rigaku, Miniflex 600). The data was collected between 2θ = 20–70° at a scan speed of 2° min−1. The tube voltage, the current and the scan step were 30 kV, 15 mA and 2.00°/min, respectively. The BET surface area and pore structure of the samples were tested after pretreatment at 200 °C under vacuum for 2 h by N2 adsorption-desorption at −196 °C (BET; ASAP 2020, Micromeritics). To examine the crystal morphology of samples, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM; Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN TMP) was performed over the reduced catalysts. The surface chemical environment was analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; Thermo Fisher, ESCALAB 250Xi) equipped with a mono-chromatic Al-K radiation source. The binding energy values were referenced to adventitious carbon (284.8 eV). The temperature-programmed reduction (TPR; Micromeritics, Autochem II 2920), temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO; Micromeritics, Autochem II 2920) and mass spectra (MS; Hidden, QIC20) were performed to explore the interactions between metal and support. The pristine calcined sample (about 200 mg) was prepared under Ar at 120 °C for 2 h and cooled to 50 °C before TPR analysis. Afterwards, 10% H2/Ar was imported, and the temperature was raised to 900 °C at the rate of 10 °C/min, and the H2 consumption was detected by the TCD detector and MS. The difference of TPO analysis is that the sample used for testing was the spent catalyst (about 80 mg) and the analyzing atmosphere was 10% O2/He, and the other conditions were the same as TPR. The metallic Rh dispersion of samples were analyzed using CO chemisorption at 35 °C after hydrogen reduction under 800 °C (CO Chemisorption; Micromeritics, ASAP 2020 Plus). The infrared spectral information was recorded in the range of 2300–1700 cm−1 using in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTS; Thermo Fisher, Nicolet 6700) equipped with an MCT/A detector. The resolution of spectra was 4 cm−1, and the signal averaging was set at 64 scans per spectrum. Firstly, approximately 100 mg of reduced catalyst was compressed and put into the sample cell, then the cell was purged with the N2 flow (10 mL/min) at 150 °C for 30 min to remove water and impurities, and subsequently cooled to 50 °C. Later, the instrument was vacuumed, and the background spectrum was recorded. After that, 25% CO/Ar was charged to the sample and the spectra were collected with absorbed pressure increasing to the steady state every 2 min. Finally, the vacuum pump was introduced to exclude the extra CO gas, and the DRIFT spectra of chemisorbed CO species were collected. Raman measurement (Raman Spectroscopy; Horiba Jobin Yvon, Labram HR Evolution) was applied to further identify the structure of samples. The excitation source was a diode laser, with a wavelength of 532 nm and nominal output power of around 0.5 mW, and the spectra were collected between 2000 and 500 cm−1. 2.3 Evaluation of catalysts Quartz tubular fixed-bed reactor (1/2 inch, inside diameter) was applied to conduct DRM reaction at 0.1 MPa. Generally, 100 mg (20–40 mesh) of sample was filled in the quartz tube. During the reduction pretreatment process, the catalyst was heated from 30 to 800 °C (heated up to 500 °C at 10 °C/min and heated up to 800 °C at 5 °C/min) under 10% H2/He, and maintaining at 800 °C for 1 h. After reduction, the sample was cooled to the pre-set reaction temperature fulfilled with helium for 1 h to remove the residual hydrogen. The reaction was operated from 550 to 800 °C at 0.1 MPa, with sampling at 50 °C intervals and each sampling temperature was kept stable for 55 min. Since DRM is a volume-changing reaction and external standard method was applied to obtain the gas content, we set up a dilute composition to reduce the experimental error. The mole ratio of feed gas was set as CO2: CH4: He = 1:1:10 and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was adjusted to 72,000 mL h−1 gcat. −1. The reactivity data was acquired every 20 min, and only the results of steady state in each temperature section were collected. The effluent gas was monitored by gas chromatograph (GC; Tianmei, GC-7900). The stability test of sample was kept at a fixed temperature for a long term and operated as the same. The conversions of CH4 and CO2 were calculated by the following formulas: X ( C H 4 ) = C H 4 ( in ) − C H 4 ( out ) C H 4 ( in ) X ( C O 2 ) = C O 2 ( in ) − C O 2 ( out ) C O 2 ( in ) where CH4/CO2(in) and CH4/CO2(out) corresponds to the molar content of CH4/CO2 at the reactor inlet and outlet, respectively. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalytic performance and stability of the catalysts The activity and stability of the catalysts were studied under steady state conditions of DRM reaction. Conversions of CH4 and CO2 were both progressively increased with the temperature since DRM is an endothermic reaction. The performance test results showed that when the amount of Zr doping is relatively low (x ≤ 10), the conversion of methane and carbon dioxide increased. But when the amount of Zr doping further increased, the performance showed a downward trend, especially when x = 50, the performance is minimized (Fig. 1 ). Rh-LTZO-10 possessed the best CH4 catalytic performance, while the CO2 conversion of Rh-LTZO-2, Rh-LTZO-5 and Rh-LTZO-10 were relatively close. At the same time, we have also synthesized a series of higher Zr-doping samples (still labelled as Rh-LTZO-x, x = 50/80/90/95/98) and conducted DRM performance tests, but the conversion of CH4 and CO2 were far lower than that of pristine Rh-LTO catalyst at any reaction temperature (Fig. S1). Subsequently, we further explored the effect of the amount of Zr doping on the performance of the reaction at 800 °C for 35 h (Fig. 2 ). The results showed that low doping amount of Zr was beneficial to the conversion of methane and carbon dioxide. With the doping amount increasing, the catalytic performance first increased, and then decreased and Rh-LTZO-10 was the most excellent catalyst among these samples. Rh-LTZO-20 was a litter inferior to pristine Rh-LTO, and the performance of Rh-LTZO-50 was awful. We also proceeded catalytic performance tests at 800 °C for 35 h on Rh-LTZO-95 and Rh-LTZO-98 (Fig. S2). Interestingly, the initial catalytic activity of Rh-LTZO-98 was not as good as that of Rh-LTO, but as the reaction progressed, its catalytic activity gradually surpassed that of Rh-LTO. However, despite this, it was still inferior to sample Rh-LTZO-10, so no further characterizations were conducted on Rh-LTZO-98. Rh-LTZO-10 has the best catalytic performance for DRM among these samples, to explore whether the improvement is caused by the doping of Zr in the pristine Rh-LTO structure, we conducted a reference experiment. 90% Rh-LTO and 10% Rh-LZO were simply mixed evenly and tested in DRM reaction, and the catalytic performance was given in Fig. S3. Undoubtedly, simple physical mixing does nothing to improve the catalytic performance and even behaves worse. The excellent performance of Rh-LTZO-10 is closely related to the doping or Zr. The equilibrium composition, CH4 and CO2 conversion were manifested in Fig. S13. From the calculated results, the CH4 and CO2 conversion could reach 97.76% at 800 °C, and H2/CO ratio was 1, but this was just an ideal reaction condition and assumed no side reactions, our experimental results were still very competitive. Also, as the DRM reaction is favorable at high temperatures, we further conducted the reaction at 850 °C over Rh-LTZO-10 sample to minimize side reactions and the evaluation results is demonstrated in Fig. S4. The conversions of CH4 and CO2 are still high and the ratio of H2/CO approaches 0.91. The main problem of the DRM reaction is the deactivation of catalyst, and the low doping amount can improve the reactivity. Therefore, we conducted a life test for Rh-LTZO-10, as controls, Rh-LTO and Rh-LTZO-20 were also assessed at the same time. From Fig. 3 , we would see that after about 50 h, the catalytic performance of all catalysts entered a stable period and ran for 200 h without activity decreasing, and the performance of each sample was consistent with the previous result in Fig. 2. We also compared our catalysts with related Rh catalysts in the literatures. These results show that the CH4 and CO2 conversions together with the stability observed on our catalysts are somewhat better than the values reported in literature at comparable conditions (Table 1 ). 3.2 Textural and structure properties of catalysts Pristine and Zr-doped catalysts were denoted as Rh-LTO and Rh-LTZO-x, where x is the mole percentage of Zr relative to Ti and the relative content of Zr is 0%; 2%; 5%; 10%; 20% and 50%, respectively. The actual Rh loadings and contents of Ti and Zr were evaluated by ICP and displayed for the Rh-LTO and Rh-LTZO-x catalysts, respectively, as shown in Table 2 . The elemental compositions of catalysts match well with those of the initial sol-gel prepared. The actual loading of Rh in all samples is about 1%. The amount of Zr and Ti element after reaction is also listed in Table 2. The element content of Zr increases, while that of Ti decreases. We speculate that after reaction, there was a certain amount of carbon depositing on the catalyst, meanwhile, Zr was more integrated into the structure than before the reaction, as the ionic radius of Zr is larger than Ti, Zr may replace a small amount of Ti, so that part of Ti was shed from the structure, resulting in the slight change of element content. The surface area and pore structure information of the samples can be obtained by N2 adsorption-desorption characterization. According to the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. 4 a), it can be seen that there are hysteresis loops in all samples, which belong to the type IV, indicating the presence of mesopores in the materials [28]. However, the shape of the hysteresis loop in the Rh-LTO-50 sample is different from other samples, suggesting the distinction in pore structure. In addition, the specific surface area of all samples is calculated by the BET model, which was small because of 900 °C calcination. According to the pore size distribution diagram (Fig. 4b), the pore size of all samples is mainly distributed around 15 nm. And it is worth noting that in the main distribution window of pore size, the Rh-LTZO-5 and Rh-LTZO-10 show higher intensity, while Rh-LTZO-50 is the lowest value. Combining the specific surface area information, which the BET surface area of the Rh-LTZO-5 and Rh-LTZO-10 showed a slight increased while Rh-LTZO-50 showed the smallest. It can be speculated that the metal Zr plays a significant role in the structure, which would cause changes in the physical and chemical properties of the material and even the catalytic performance. To investigate the phase change after Zr doping, we performed powder XRD characterization on the samples and the results were exhibited in Fig. 5 a. All the catalysts showed the spectra basically match with the standard XRD spectrum of La2Ti2O7 (PDF: 28–0517) except the Rh-LTZO-50 sample, and the peaks were slightly shifted due to doping with Rh and Zr. The diffraction pattern of Rh-LTZO-50 was quite disparate from other samples, since the contents of Zr were much higher, which reconstructed the initial La2Ti2O7 (PDF: 28–0517) framework and made the sample structure closer to La2Zr2O7 (PDF: 17–0450). There is no correlation peak of Rh observed, suggesting that the Rh species may be widely dispersed. To explore the peak shift after Zr doping, we used corundum (α-Al2O3) as an internal standard for correction (Fig. 5b). Magnifying and observing the characteristic peaks in the catalysts in the 2θ range of 24–34°, it could be found that all characteristic peaks of samples shifted to lower 2θ values due to Zr doping compared to Rh-LTO. And as the amount of Zr increased, the deviation degree of the characteristic peaks increased, the Rh-LTZO-20 performed the maximum. It is believed that the peak shifting is due to structural disorder or lattice strain [29]. According to the Bragg's Law (2dsinθ = nλ), when the lattice spacing d increases, the value of θ decreases, which means that the large ionic radius Zr4+ (ionic radius r = 0.072 nm) replaces part of the Ti4+ (r = 0.061 nm) in the structure of catalysts. However, as the amount of Zr further increased to 50%, the structure dominated by La2Zr2O7 appeared in the Rh-LTZO-50. In addition, a similar phenomenon was observed in the Raman characteristic vibration peak spectrum (Fig. S5). When Zr is low doping, the Raman spectrum is close to La2Ti2O7. Low-frequency signals from 100 to 410 cm−1 are assigned to the La−O vibrations, peaks around 543 and 605 cm−1 are attributed to the vibration of distorted TiO6 octahedron, and the characteristic signal around 800 cm−1 could be attributed to the vibrations of Ti−O stretching mode [30,31]. The Rh-LTZO-50 exhibited different characteristic peaks from others, indicating that its structure has changed with the increase of Zr content, and the Raman signals of it are closer to La2Zr2O7. The bands at ca. 300, 400 and 500 cm−1 are designated as bending vibrations of O−Zr−O, stretching vibrations of La−O and bending vibrations of ZrO6 octahedra, respectively [32,33]. With the increase of Zr doping amount, the characteristic signal at 800 cm−1, which ascribed to Ti−O stretching mode, red-shifted to low frequencies, implying the weakening of Ti−O bond. These phenomena further confirm our previous speculation that Zr has partially substituted Ti in the structure. The effect of different Zr doping amount on the Rh morphology and structure of Rh-LTZO-x material after reduction were studied by TEM and HAADF-STEM. The TEM images were displayed in Fig. 6 and the HAADF-STEM images were given in Fig. S6-S11. Obviously, Rh nanoparticles present in all samples except Rh-LTZO-50, while there are Rh elements in the EDS-mapping energy spectrum of Rh-LTZO-50 (Fig. S11), indicating that Rh nanoparticles in Rh-LTZO-50 are too tiny to be observed. The size of Rh nanoparticles of Rh-LTO and Rh-LTZO-5 is around 1.4 nm, while that of Rh-LTZO-2 and Rh-LTZO-10 is around 2.2 nm, although there are some differences, they are not significant enough. Rh nanoparticles are also not noticeable in Rh-LTZO-20 in TEM, this is because of insufficient contrast. In fact, there are clear Rh nanoparticles in HAADF-STEM image, together with EDS-mapping (Fig. S10). Through the above characterizations of samples, it is found that when the doping amount of Zr is low, the main structure of Rh-LTZO-x is still La2Ti2O7, but it has become distorted. The XRD and Raman characteristic peaks of Rh-LTZO-x (x ≤ 20) have shifted compared with Rh-LTO, revealing that part of Zr element replaced Ti in the La2Ti2O7 structure. Besides, the TEM and HAADF-STEM results prove that Rh nanoparticles are existed in all samples when x ≤ 20, while the size and distribution of these particles need to be further analyzed in combination with other experiments. The evidence proves that when x ≤ 20, the interaction between Rh and the support would change due to the partial substitution of Zr for Ti sites, and the support structure being distorted accordingly. When the doping amount of Zr further increases to 50%, the characterization results of Rh-LTZO-50 are disparate from other samples. Firstly, the hysteresis loop of N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm is peculiar, and the BET surface area is much smaller. Then the XRD pattern manifests that there are both characteristic peaks of La2Ti2O7 and La2Zr2O7 in Rh-LTZO-50 sample, and the signals of La2Zr2O7 are stronger than La2Ti2O7. Finally, the Raman peaks are different, and we can hardly find noticeable Rh nanoparticles in the TEM diagram. All the physical properties of catalysts disclose that when the doping amount of Zr rises to 50%, the initial structure of LTO support alters tremendously, and the existence form of the active Rh in the structure is also great affected, which influences the catalytic performance of Rh-LTZO-50 sample in DRM reaction. Next, we would further analyze the chemical properties of the samples. 3.3 Chemical properties of catalysts The reducibility of the oxidation precursor has a profound influence on the properties of the catalyst. Hence, we conducted temperature-programmed-reduction (Fig. 7 a) measurements to characterize the interaction of metal-support. Our previous research has found that the support is a very stable material (Fig. S14a exhibits the H2-TPR diagram of only support LTZO), so the reduction peaks in TPR can basically be attributed to the reduction of Rh oxide, and there are two types of Rh in Rh-LTO and they perform two reduction peaks in TPR (ca. 250 °C is attributed to Rh2O3 on the surface with weakly interaction and ca. 380 °C is ascribed to Rh−O located on the lattice with strongly interaction) [20]. With the doping amount of Zr gradually rises until 20%, the reduction peaks shift to high temperature, meanwhile, the reduction peak area at around 250 °C increases first and then decreases, reaching a maximum value at 10%, while the change of the peak at ca. 380 °C is almost negligible. The results demonstrate that in Rh-LTZO-10 sample, there may be the largest number of Rh2O3 with weakly interaction, which is easily reduced to the metallic state to become the active site of the reaction, and this may accelerate the redox cycle of the DRM reaction. We surmise that when x ≤ 20, the main structure of support remains, the doping of Zr has just conducted to lattice distortion, affecting the distribution of Rh in the structure and in turn affects the Rh-support interaction. For Rh-LTZO-50 sample, the characteristic bands appear at around 330 °C and 630 °C, which are also different from others, and the peak area at 330 °C is small. It could be figured that Rh in Rh-LTZO-50 sample is hardly to be reduced, leading to fewer active sites and poor catalytic performance, which is proved in the reaction data of DRM. The experiment results of CO2-TPD (Fig. 7b) are also like the other previous characterizations, meanwhile, the CO2-TPD diagrams of LTZO support were displayed in Fig. S14b. It could be conducted that the acid-basic properties of catalysts mainly depended on the support. When the doping amount of Zr does not exceed 20%, the signals of Rh-LTZO-x (x ≤ 20) and Rh-LTO are almost the same, indicating that their sensitivity to CO2 is basically identical. The desorption peak of Rh-LTZO-50 is much smaller, the adsorption capacity of CO2 is not strong, which may affect the catalytic performance. We have had a general understanding of the reducibility of the samples, and the possible existence forms of the active Rh in the structure through the previous outcomes. To analyze the electronic environment of Rh and the distribution of active oxygen and lattice oxygen in the structure, we conducted XPS analysis of all samples. For all calcined samples, there was only a pair of Rh 3d peaks in the pattern (Fig. 8 a), which could be ascribed to Rh3+ species [34]. As for O 1s signals (Fig. 8b), all the samples acquired two peaks, the peak around 529.3 eV was assigned to lattice oxygen (Olattice) and the peak at 531.5 eV was considered as surface adsorbed oxygen (Oadsorbed) [35]. The XPS patterns of samples after reduction was given in Fig. 9 . Obviously, there were two kinds of Rh species, the bands at 306.6 eV were the metallic Rh0 species and the higher signals represented Rhδ+. It could be found that the Rh species on the catalyst surface were not completely reduced, leading to the formation of Rhδ+ species. Comparing the relative content of Rh0 and Rhδ+ species in all samples by semi-quantitative analysis, the Rh-LTZO-10 maintains the largest amount of Rh0, indicating that there are the most of Rh species that can be reduced to metallic Rh in Rh-LTZO-10 sample. This assumption is consistent with the former H2-TPR result that Rh-LTZO-10 keeps the largest reduction peak area. The changes of O 1s are inconspicuous, which could be explained that there are plenty of O in the structure and the variation is slight. The O in the structure needs to be analyzed in combination with other characterizations. To further observe the bonding environment of samples, we carried out XANES characterization (Fig. 10 ) on partial representative samples limited by experimental conditions. For Rh element, the signal of Rh-LTZO-20 is the closest to standard Rh2O3, followed by Rh-LZO, and Rh-LTO is closer to Rh foil. We could conclude that the bonding of Rh elements in Rh-LTZO-20 is more likely to that of Rh in Rh2O3. In Fig. 10b, the white line of all samples is below the standard ZrO2, which means that Zr in samples is not in the form of ordinary ZrO2. Comparing the Zr K-edge profiles, Zr in Rh-LTZO-5 has the highest oxidation state, followed by Rh-LTZO-10 and Rh-LTZO-20, and Rh-LTZO-50 is close to Rh-LZO. As the amount of Zr increases (x ≤ 20), the valence of it decreases, in other words, Zr is in a high oxidation state and could adsorb the surrounding electrons, reducing the electron density of surrounding elements. While the Zr in Rh-LTZO-50 is like Rh-LZO, thus we further believe that there is a part of La2Zr2O7 structure in Rh-LTZO-50, and it is observed in XRD pattern. To further judge the Rh species in samples, we selected Rh-LTZO-5 as the typical sample and performed CO in-situ DRIFTS characterization on it and compared with Rh-L(T/Z)O (Fig. 11 ). The results show that Rh have multiple states on Rh-LTZO-5, including both symmetrical adsorption peaks at 2010 and 2080 cm−1 and linear adsorption peaks near 2060 cm−1, which is similar to Rh-LZO; and a bridge absorption peak at 1840 cm−1, that is similar in Rh-LTO. When the CO pressure increases, it is found that the linear absorption peak blue-shifts from 2062 to 2058 cm−1. This phenomenon indicates that the Rh−Rh bonds exist in the structure of Rh-LTZO-5 after reduction, which means there are Rh nanoparticles, and they are indeed observed in HR-TEM. But there are adsorption peaks also similar to Rh-LZO, so we speculate that there are also Rh−O bonds in the structure [20,36,37]. It is another evidence which verifies the presence of Rh in metal and oxidation states on Rh-LTZO-5. The Rh-LTZO-10 catalyst possessed the largest Rh dispersion, the most reducible Rh species, the most Rh0 species and lattice oxygen, besides, the pore size distribution is concentrated, and the particle size of Rh particles is moderate, which could explain that why the Rh-LTZO-10 catalyst performs better than other catalysts. 3.4 Properties of catalysts after reaction and reaction mechanism After the 35-h reaction, we operated XRD detection (Fig. 12 ) on the phase of the samples and found that these structures were almost unchanged compared with the sample before the reaction. Analogously, magnifying and observing the characteristic peaks in the catalysts in the range of 2θ = 28–31° can be found that all samples characteristic peaks still shifted to lower 2θ values compared to Rh-LTO after reaction, which means that the structure has a good thermal stability. Thermal stability is important for catalysts, and another criterion is the carbon deposition on catalyst surface. Raman spectroscopy and O2-TPOCO2-MS (Fig. S12) were applied to investigate the coke formation (partial samples, limited by experimental conditions). According to our previous study, we know that the amount of carbon deposit on Rh-LTO after 70 h reaction is insignificant compared to Rh-LZO which only reacted for 25 h[20]. However, when we compare Rh-LTZO-5 that has been reacted for 300 h with Rh-LTO that has only been reacted for 70 h, we find that the amount of carbon deposited on Rh-LTZO-5 is almost negligible. Similarly, among O2-TPOCO2-MS, the Rh-LTZO-5 shows the smallest amount of peak area, and it only has a CO2 characteristic peak around 260 °C, this peak can be classified as polymeric carbon (Cα) and it can be oxidized easily, the oxidation peak at 336 °C and 468 °C could ascribed to filamentous carbon (Cβ) and signals beyond 600 °C would be considered as graphitic carbon (Cγ)[38]. Carrying out semi-quantitative analysis of coke according to TPO data, the coke amount of Rh-LTZO-5 (low Zr doping) was about 1/3 of Rh-LTO, while the coke amount of Rh-LZO was almost 10 times of Rh-LTO. Therefore, we speculate that when an appropriate amount of Zr is doped into Rh-LTO, it can not only improve its activity and stability, but also greatly reduce the formation of carbon deposits. We found that Rh-LTZO-5 possesses good anti-carbon ability, while Rh-LTZO-10 has almost the same structure as Rh-LTZO-5, so we did not repeat the analysis of carbon deposition. And in the following TEM analysis, we had not observed carbon nanotubes in the pattern of Rh-LTZO-10 after 200-h life test. When we observed the 35-h spent catalyst by TEM (Fig. 13 ), it was found that the Rh nanoparticles in the samples agglomerated and grew up to varying degrees, the dispersion of Rh in Rh-LTZO-10 was the best, followed by Rh-LTZO-5, and the most serious agglomeration of Rh happened in Rh-LTZO-50. The particle size in samples match their performance, the Rh-LTZO-10 sample with the smallest Rh nanoparticles has the best catalytic performance. The TEM images of samples after 200-h stability test are listed in Fig. 14 . Even after 200-h reaction, there was no serious Rh agglomeration in Rh-LTZO-10, while it was already observed in Rh-LTZO-20 at this time. And it is worth noting that no obvious carbon deposits were observed on both of samples, which indicated that the Rh-based LTZO oxygen composite metal oxide has a good ability to resist carbon deposition. The XPS analysis is also used to characterize the electronic environment around each element in the samples after 200-h reaction. For Rh 3d signals (Fig. 15 a), there are still two kinds of Rh species in the pattern, while in Rh-LTZO-10 and Rh-LTZO-20, after long-term DRM reaction, the peak position representing Rhδ+ species shifted towards lower binding energy. This may be because the products (H2 and CO) generated by the DRM reaction have a strong reducing ability, resulting in the partial reduction of Rhδ+ species. It could be inferred that during the reaction, Rh participate in the electron transfer process as the active species, so the binding energies change accordingly. After 200-h reaction, the binding energies of O 1s also altered (Fig. 15b). Peaks around 529.5 eV are ascribed to lattice oxygen and bands around 532.0 eV are surface adsorbed oxygen. Both binding energies shifted to higher binding energy, this may be influenced by the oxygen species produced by the decomposition of CO2. It is reasonable to speculate that, in addition to the active Rh species, O in the Rh-LTZO-x structure is also a pivotal species involved in the reaction. For Ti 2p and Zr 3d signals (Fig. 15c and d), the distinction between the different samples is not obvious, with the increase of Zr doping amount, the binding energy of Ti and Zr almost unchanged. With the change of Zr and Ti content in the sample, an electronic perturbation on Rh become obvious through the interactions between Rh and substrates, even if the change of binding energy is inconspicuous. Besides, we semi-quantitatively analyzed the relative content of different Rh species and O species in samples by XPS and the data is displayed in Table 3 . It could be found that the Rhδ+ species in Rh-LTO increased slightly, while the content of surface adsorbed oxygen in Rh-LTO rose, as there would be oxygen-containing species involved in the DRM reaction. Things were analogous in Rh-LTZO-10, the content of Rhδ+ species leapt from 43.74% to 61.28%, and the surface adsorbed oxygen also grew up. The Rhδ+ species in Rh-LTZO-20 increased too, but the content of surface adsorbed oxygen reduced, different from the other two samples. Combined with the catalytic performance of samples that Rh-LTZO-10 was the most excellent catalyst and Rh-LTZO-20 was inferior to Rh-LTO, we inferred that electron transfer played a key role in the reaction, the decline of surface adsorbed oxygen was the reason that Rh-LTZO-20 exhibited poorer activity. The different doping amount of Zr has different effects on the structure, and when x = 10, the migration speed or migration number of electrons in the structure increase, which increases the reactivity; and when the content of Zr further rises to 20%, Zr restrains the migration of electrons, reducing or inhibiting the generation of surface adsorbed oxygen in the structure, which affects the activity. Combining the catalyst evaluation outcomes with all the characterization results, it could be inferred that there were strong interactions between the Rh species and the LTZO support. When the doping amount of Zr is at a low level, Zr has partially replaced Ti in support, the main structure of LTZO support has not changed significantly, the tiny distortion makes transfer of electrons easier, the Rh nanoparticles are more likely to participate in chemical reaction cycles, meanwhile, the content of surface adsorbed oxygen has increased, which is easier to remove the carbon deposition to maintain a durable catalyst. If the Zr amount is too high, the main structure of support would be destroyed, resulting in the poor catalytic performance. 4 Conclusion By optimizing the composition of Rh-LTZO-x, we found that different amounts of Zr doping played dissimilar roles in the structure of Rh-LTZO-x. When the doping amount of Zr is at a low level, the Rh-LTZO-x catalyst can effectively improve the conversion and stability of DRM reaction, and Zr partially replaces the Ti site, affecting the Rh and O species in the structure, resulting in the distinctions of valence distribution and electron density, which may accelerates the transfer rate or amount of electrons during the reaction; and when the doping amount of Zr is at a high level, Zr element in the sample is more likely to form La2Zr2O7 structure, which has adverse side effects on DRM reaction. Our research provides a way to explore high-activity and high-stability catalysts for methane dry reforming in the future. coredata.dc:description: Zr doped Rh-La2Ti2O7 with different amounts of Zr were prepared with a sol-gel process and used as catalysts for dry reforming of methane. The samples as prepared were characterized by a series of methods including powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS), and temperature-programmed reduction (TPR). The XPS and XAS spectra revealed the effect of doped Zr in the electronic environment of catalysts. The results showed that when the doping amount of Zr was at a low level, the activity and stability of the DRM catalyst were significantly improved. Tests of catalytic activity showed that the reforming performance of Rh-LTZO-x catalysts was affected by the Zr/Ti loading ratio. It was favored when Zr/Ti ratio was low and incomplete methane conversion was observed when Zr/Ti=1. Compared to Rh-LTO, the optimized catalyst Rh-LTZO-10 enhanced conversion of methane and carbon dioxide from 77% to 86%, 83% to 90%, respectively. The optimized catalyst Rh-LTZO-10 exhibited long stability life over 200 h of the reaction and there was only a small amount of carbon deposition. The low amount of Zr doping may accelerate the transfer rate or number of electrons during the reaction, enhance the interaction between the active component Rh and the support, so that Rh can stably exist in the structure and achieve long stability in DRM reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Doping low amount of Zirconium in Rh-LTO to prepare durable catalysts for dry reforming of methane
